title: How to Check a Start Capacitor

steps.title: Locate the capacitor inside your appliance.
steps.content: Locate the capacitor inside your appliance. Capacitors are metal tubes that store an electric charge usually found near a motor in the appliance. Use a screwdriver to open your machine and locate the capacitor. Use needle-nose pliers with an insulated handle to remove wires. [1] X Research source Make sure your device is unplugged and turned off before you find the capacitor.

steps.title: Use a screwdriver with an insulated handle.
steps.content: Use a screwdriver with an insulated handle. Find or purchase the screwdriver from a hardware store. The rubber will prevent electricity from traveling through the metal to your hand. [2] X Research source Use caution when working with electricity. A strong enough shock can cause serious harm or death. Make sure the screwdriver’s handle doesn’t have any cracks and that no bit of metal is sticking out the back. This could carry voltage and cause you serious harm.

steps.title: Wear a pair of gloves meant for housework or working with electricity.
steps.content: Wear a pair of gloves meant for housework or working with electricity. Since you’re using an insulated screwdriver, work gloves will work fine. For added protection against electricity, use tight-gripping gloves made with rubber. [3] X Research source Gloves can be purchased at your local hardware or home improvement store. Don’t use large rubber gloves because they will give you less dexterity while you’re working.

steps.title: Hold the handle of the screwdriver so no part of your hand touches the metal.
steps.content: Hold the handle of the screwdriver so no part of your hand touches the metal. Have a firm grip on the handle, making sure you aren’t in contact with the metal. Even with gloves, the current running through the shaft can cause you harm. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Place the shaft of the screwdriver on the positive terminal.
steps.content: Place the shaft of the screwdriver on the positive terminal. Set the screwdriver down so the terminal contacts the shaft 1 inch (2.5 cm) from the tip. The correct terminal will be marked with a plus sign (+). Make sure the screwdriver doesn’t touch the other terminal on the capacitor yet. [5] X Research source On a capacitor with more than 2 terminals, the positive terminal may be labeled “common” instead.

steps.title: Tap the negative terminal with the tip of the screwdriver.
steps.content: Tap the negative terminal with the tip of the screwdriver. While maintaining contact with the positive terminal, tilt the screwdriver so you make contact with the negative terminal. Once you make the connection, you’ll hear a small pop and see a spark on the tip of the screwdriver. Don’t be alarmed; this is the capacitor discharging completely. [6] X Research source Do not hold onto the metal part of the screwdriver while making the connection. Capacitors can store a lot of energy and the resulting spark or current can result in serious injury.

steps.title: Connect the terminals again to remove any residual charge.
steps.content: Connect the terminals again to remove any residual charge. After the initial spark, keep the screwdriver on the terminals and tap the negative side with the tip 1 or 2 more times. Sometimes, leftover charge is still left in the capacitor. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Use the capacitance setting on a digital multimeter.
steps.content: Use the capacitance setting on a digital multimeter. Multimeters are electronic devices that read the voltage and capacitance of circuits or batteries. Find a multimeter with a dedicated capacitance setting for the most accurate readings. [8] X Research source Make sure the capacitor you’re testing is completely discharged or the circuit is off before using a multimeter. Too high of a voltage can damage the meter or cause you harm. Digital multimeters can be purchased hardware or home improvement stores. Capacitance is measured in farads (F).

steps.title: Place the red probe on the positive terminal and the black probe on the negative.
steps.content: Place the red probe on the positive terminal and the black probe on the negative. Hold the probes by their base without touching the metal pins on the end. Once both probes come into contact with the terminals on your capacitor, the readout on your multimeter will start to change. [9] X Research source Wear gloves while testing with a multimeter if you’re worried about any residual charge.

steps.title: Hold the probes in place until the numbers stop changing.
steps.content: Hold the probes in place until the numbers stop changing. The numbers will fluctuate for a few seconds after you connect the terminals if the capacitor is good. Wait until the readout has the same number for 5 seconds before disconnecting the probes. [10] X Research source Write down the capacitance number after you take a measurement so you can remember it. If the numbers do not move at all, the capacitor is considered open and needs to be replaced.

steps.title: Ensure the reading matches the range of numbers on the capacitor.
steps.content: Ensure the reading matches the range of numbers on the capacitor. The minimum and maximum capacitance are listed on the side of the capacitor with all of its other information. The acceptable range depends on the size of the capacitor you have. If the capacitor is above or below the range, it will have to be replaced. [11] X Research source If the capacitance number went up infinitely to the limit of your multimeter, the capacitor has shorted out and should be replaced. Some capacitors will have a set capacitance with an acceptable percentage of variance. For example, if your capacitor says “50 ±5%,” the acceptable capacitance range is 47.5 to 52.5 F.
